titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Meriden Gravure Company Records
titlestmt.author: by Andrea Benefiel and Ellen Doon

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:14

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.physdesc: (361 boxes) + 1 broadside folder and 1 art object
did.abstract: The Records consist of correspondence, office files, estimates, orders, cost recapitulation forms, proofs, and other material documenting the work of the Meriden Gravure Company, a printing company that rose to prominence in the early twentieth century through specialization in high-fidelity image reproduction.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Meriden-Stinehour Press, 1981-1989, and Stinehour Press, 2006; five additional boxes transferred from Arts of the Book Collection, 2005-2006.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Meriden Gravure Company Records are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Meriden Gravure Company Records. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The records remain largely in their original order as received from the Meriden Gravure Company, although some shifting was done to arrange material that was out of sequence within series. A number of large-format proof sets for books printed by Meriden Gravure and duplicate copies of a sample postcard prospectus were removed from the collection during processing and discarded. Published books were removed for separate cataloging or discard.

bioghist.head: Meriden Gravure Company
bioghist.p: The Meriden Gravure Company was founded in Meriden, Connecticut, in 1888 by Charles Parker and James F. Allen, and grew out of an earlier printing endeavor by Parker.

Driven by the needs of the local silver industry, the company early developed an expertise in high quality image reproduction. It perfected the use of the full-tone collotype printing method, and soon attracted business from other clients who required highly detailed image reproduction, including scientific journals, museums, libraries, and publishers of illustrated books. By the mid-twentieth century, the company was also using offset printing presses, for which it pioneered the use of the fine screened 300-line halftone process for art reproduction and scholarly facsimiles. Both reproduction methods were in use through 1967, when the collotype presses were retired. The company first offered color printing in the 1940s. Through careful quality control, including an insistence on photographing directly from the item to be reproduced and using high quality paper, Meriden Gravure achieved a reputation of consistent excellence in printed illustration.

In addition to an extensive list of academic and museum clients, Meriden Gravure enjoyed steady business from the commercial sphere. The General Electric Company was one of its biggest accounts, as was the United States government (the company earned classified status during World War II).

A driving force behind Meriden Gravure's success from the late 1920s on was E. Harold Hugo (1910-1985), who devoted his entire career to the company. After assisting at age fourteen with experiments to improve the collotype process, he remained dedicated to constant improvements in the quality of reproduction. His passion for fine presswork was additionally enhanced by the influence of printer Gregg Anderson, who worked at the company from 1932 to 1935. Hugo was, by all accounts, an inspired company director and its most energetic salesman. While he never finished college, his expertise and advocacy of fine printing earned him numerous honorary degrees, including an M.A. from Yale in 1963.

The Meriden Gravure Company had a natural counterpart in the Stinehour Press of Lunenberg, Vermont, which was devoted to high quality letterpress printing. The two companies were closely related and often collaborated; Hugo had been on Stinehour's Board of Directors since it was founded in the 1950s. Anticipating Hugo's retirement, the companies merged in 1977. Meriden-Stinehour Press maintained operations in both locations through 1989, when it closed the Meriden operation and moved the presses to Vermont.

Administrative Timeline:
1888 Meriden Gravure Company founded, Meriden, Connecticut
1890 James F. Allen begins as President
1924 Everett Harold Hugo begins work at MGC while in high school
1928 James F. Allen dies; his son Parker Allen becomes President; Hugo drops out of Northeastern University to help run the company
1942-1945 Parker Allen serves in armed forces; Hugo becomes Manager
1943 Hugo becomes Vice President
1962 Hugo becomes President
1975 John Peckham becomes President; Hugo becomes Vice Chairman
1977 MGC merges with Stinehour Press, becoming Meriden-Stinehour Press. Hugo is Chair of the Board
1989 Meriden facility is closed, all operations move to Lunenberg, Vermont

The following works were consulted in preparing this summary:
Peckham, John F. Adventures in printing : a talk on the career of Harold Hugo given at the Club of Odd Volumes . Lunenburg, VT : Stinehour Press, [1995?].
Walker, Gay, Harold Hugo & the Meriden Gravure Company . Wilsonville, Or. : G. Walker, 1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Records consist of correspondence, office files, estimates, orders, cost recapitulation forms, proofs, and other material documenting the operation of the Meriden Gravure Company, a commercial printing company that rose to prominence in the early twentieth century through specialization in high-fidelity image reproduction. The records span the dates 1895 to 1990, with the bulk of the material falling between 1900 and 1977.

The records document the work of the company, including its history, internal culture, relationships with clients, and the business of printing. Correspondence between the printing plant in Meriden and the company's New York office documents the internal workings of the company. Correspondence with clients documents specific printing projects, as well as the company's attention to customer's needs. Correspondence can be found throughout the first three series, Office Files, Correspondence, 1900-1959 (arranged largely alphabetically) and Correspondence, 1960-1981 (arranged chronologically), and in Series V. Estimates. Specific print jobs can also be tracked using an order index located in Series V. Orders; the company used an order numbering system that appears to correspond between Series V. Orders, Series VI. Estimates, and Series VII. Recapitulation Forms.

The collection contains numerous examples of the company's work, mostly in proof form, and to some extent documents the technical processes that made it such a success. Of particular interest is a volume of typescript and hand-drawn instructions titled "Collotype Printing" by Arthur Sias, found in Series VII. Financial and Business Records. A run of "Office Records," also in Series VII. is a detailed record of the daily operation of the printing presses from 1895 to 1922.

Examples of the company's detailed reproductions exist chiefly in the Printed Material series, which contains finished samples as well as proofs. Earlier examples such as silver catalogs and postcards exhibit the detail achieved through the collotype process, while later work, such as proofs for Leonard Baskin's illustrations for the Divine Comedy , showcase the company's offset work. Proofs can also be found on the verso of interoffice correspondence.

The records also document the career of E. Harold Hugo, whose personal office files, within the Office Files series, include papers relating to his sales trips for the company, but also files related to his involvement with Old Sturbridge Village and other outside concerns. Hugo's files also include examples of printed matter collected from a number of other presses.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are organized into nine series: I. Office Files. II. Correspondence, 1900-1959. III. Correspondence, 1960-1981. IV. Orders. V. Estimates. VI. Recapitulation Forms. VII. Financial and Business Records. VIII. Printed Materials. IX. Meriden-Stinehour, Inc. Records.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I. Office Files is arranged in alphabetical order by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. Office Files documents the operations of the company between about 1933 and 1984. The files include both internal company correspondence and client correspondence, and reflect the activities of various company personnel as well as the Committee to Honor Harold Hugo (circa 1975 to 1980).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. Correspondence, 1900-1959 contains general correspondence of the Meriden Gravure Company, including inter-office correspondence and client correspondence. Within General Correspondence, New York Correspondence is comprised of memoranda exchanged between Meriden Gravure Company offices in Meriden, Connecticut and New York City. Correspondence continues in Series III., reflecting a change in the company's filing system in 1960.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II. is organized into two subseries: General Correspondence and Named Correspondent Files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Named Correspondent Files are arranged in alphabetical order by correspondent or client.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III. is organized into three subseries: Scientific Correspondence, New York Correspondence and Other Correspondence. Each subseries is arranged chronologically. Within Other Correspondence, the files for each year are arranged alphabetically by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III. Correspondence, 1960-1981 contains internal and external business correspondence documenting the printing services and operations of the Meriden Gravure Company during the latter part of the twentieth century. The Scientific Correspondence subseries consists of correspondence with scientific clients of Meriden Gravure Company. The New York Correspondence subseries contains memoranda exchanged between Meriden Gravure's offices in Meriden, Connecticut and New York City. Other Correspondence consists of general client correspondence. This second correspondence series reflects a change in the company's filing system in 1960.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV. Orders contains order forms and order index cards circa 1940 to 1985. Orders, estimators' worksheets (in Series V.), and recaps (in Series VI.) are stamped in the upper right corner with an order number, which appears to correspond between records. The index cards located in this series correlate client names, job order numbers and dates and may be used to reference specific print jobs. Though dates are not present on all order forms, bundles of sheets were dated on the outer packaging.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV. is organized into two subseries: Order Index and Order Forms. Order Index is arranged alphabetically by customer name. Order Forms are arranged chronologically and by order number.

did.unittitle: Order Index Transfers A-J (mostly from 1960 on)
Order Index Transfers K-Z (mostly from 1960 on)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series V. is organized into three subseries: Estimators' Worksheets: Alphabetical; Estimators' Worksheets: Chronological;and Other Estimates. Within Other Estimates, estimate cards are organized into three alphabetically arranged groups, roughly reflecting the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s, though some overlapping does occur.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V. Estimates is comprised of worksheets, correspondence and index cards pertaining to the estimation of print job costs from circa 1930 to 1977. Though dates are not present on all estimate worksheets, bundles of sheets were dated on the outer packaging. In the Estimators' Worksheets: Chronological subseries, gaps exist between 1933 and 1936 and also between 1940 and 1954.

did.unittitle: Merrymount Press - University of Pennsylvania Museum

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Estimators' Worksheets: Chronological are arranged also by order number.

did.unittitle: Estimate Books, General, Commercial and Scientific
Estimate Books, Commercial and Scientific, General Electric, New Britain Machine Company, Pratt and Whitney, and Princeton University
Estimate Books, State and U. S. Government and Transfers

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VI. is arranged chronologically and by order number. Typically each year has a corresponding letter beginning the order numbers. Some order numbers seem to be out of sequence, and were arranged according to the date on the outer packaging. In cases where bundles were not dated, sheets are arranged by order number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI. Recapitulation Forms contains cost recapitulation forms spanning 1937 to 1957. Though dates are not present on all forms, bundles of sheets were dated on the outer packaging. There is a significant gap in the records between 1951 and 1957.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VII. is arranged roughly by format.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VII. Financial and Business Records contains general records, office records (concerning operation of the printing presses), scientific customer information forms, ledger sheets and balance books, and transfer and shipment reports. Highlights include a map of the Meriden Gravure Company building from 1908 and log books documenting the earliest Meriden Gravure print jobs, from 1897 to 1919.

did.unittitle: Layout of Building, "Collotype Printing" by Arthur Sias

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VIII. is organized into four subseries: Proofs, Silver Catalogs, Post Cards, and Miscellaneous Printed Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VIII. Printed Material contains proofs, file copies, and final copies of material printed by Meriden Gravure Company, spanning 1907 to 1974. It includes proofs of Leonard Baskin's illustrations for Dante's Divine Comedy , proofs of dog sketches by Marguerite Kirmse, and proofs of silver catalogs from 1907 to 1941.

did.unittitle: Kirmse, Marguerite, b. 1885. Proofs of sketches.
Final collotype printed by the Meriden Gravure Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Proof sheet featuring various Bernard Picture Company images. Signed by five Meriden Gravure employees.

arrangement.p: Post Cards are arranged alphabetically by client name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IX. Meriden-Stinehour, Inc. Records consists of one box of materials documenting the operations of Meriden-Stinehour, Inc. Included are financial statements and miscellaneous printed materials.

did.unittitle: Meriden-Stinehour, Inc. records and printed material
